document_title: Biofilm formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in spaceflight is minimized on lubricant impregnated surfaces
summary_full: This study investigated the formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms on stainless steel (SS316 and passivated SS316) and lubricant-impregnated surfaces (LIS) in spaceflight (microgravity) compared to Earth-based conditions. Biofilms in microgravity were found to be less robust, with significantly reduced biomass, thickness, and surface area coverage compared to those grown on Earth. The LIS material demonstrated a strong inhibition of biofilm formation, an effect that was even more pronounced in microgravity than on Earth. Transcriptomic analysis revealed differences in gene expression between the surfaces and gravitational conditions, suggesting potential mechanisms for biofilm reduction on LIS, including altered expression of genes related to virulence factors like pyochelin and rhamnolipids, and possible repulsion by immobilized nucleic acids on the LIS surface. The findings highlight LIS as a promising strategy for controlling bacterial biofilms in spacecraft.
key_findings: Biofilm formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is significantly reduced in microgravity compared to Earth conditions, in terms of biomass, thickness, and surface area coverage.
Lubricant-impregnated surfaces (LIS) strongly inhibit biofilm formation of P. aeruginosa, with this effect being more pronounced in microgravity than on Earth.
Stainless steel surfaces (SS316 and pSS316) showed similar biofilm formation characteristics in both gravitational conditions, with biofilms growing throughout the surface.
LIS surfaces showed restricted biofilm growth with sharp edges, and in microgravity, biofilms were minimized and mostly present as small cell groups.
Transcriptomic analysis indicated altered gene expression in microgravity on SS, including increased expression of pyochelin-related genes, suggesting potential increased virulence.
A proposed mechanism for LIS's anti-biofilm effect involves the immobilization of nucleic acids on the surface, creating a negatively charged layer that repels bacteria.
future_research_fields: Investigating the precise mechanisms of biofilm inhibition on LIS, including the role of immobilized nucleic acids and protein denaturation.
Characterizing the function of uncharacterized differentially expressed genes identified in microgravity biofilms.
Long-term studies to assess the stability and potential delayed biofilm formation on LIS.
Exploring the use of immobilized DNA/RNA on surfaces as an alternative anti-biofilm strategy for spacecraft.
Conducting proteomic analyses to confirm transcriptomic findings at the protein level.
Studying the impact of LIS on bacterial virulence and antimicrobial resistance in more detail.

conclusions: Biofilm formation of Pseudomonas aeruginosa is significantly reduced in microgravity compared to Earth, and lubricant-impregnated surfaces (LIS) are highly effective at inhibiting this formation, even more so in spaceflight. LIS represents a promising strategy for controlling bacterial biofilms on spacecraft components.
impact_statement: This research offers a promising solution for mitigating the risks posed by bacterial biofilms in spacecraft, enhancing the safety and reliability of space missions.
